"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2016-08-23 07:23:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/mistral/commit/f6a2ce6399c3e51c43bedaa452d79695a5616033', 'message': "Change execution mechanism for 'join' tasks

* In order to avoid duplicates of same 'join' tasks we now use
  named locks to exclusively create a task execution for 'join'
  tasks in DB. Transaction that does that is always separate
  from task completion logic and is very short. This is needed

  that can potentially be used for squashing delayed calls
  by scheduler itself (not implemented yet)
* Adjusted Scheduler implementation and tests accordingly

commit_message:
Change execution mechanism for 'join' tasks

* In order to avoid duplicates of same 'join' tasks we now use
  named locks to exclusively create a task execution for 'join'
  tasks in DB. Transaction that does that is always separate
  from task completion logic and is very short. This is needed
  to eliminate DB contention on same records of task execution
  table. This is also a reason to use a separate mechanism such
  as named locks, and additionally this reduces a number possible
  scenarios for getting into deadlocks because for task executions
  we have too many different access patterns that can lead to them
  in case of doing locking on right on their table records.
  So this approach guarantees that there's only one transaction
  creates a new task execution object for 'join' task and schedules
  'refresh_task_state' job that check 'join' completion.
* Dropped scheduler 'unique_key' column with unique constraint
  because in practice it causes DB deadlocks (at least on MySQL)
  while simultaneously inserting and updating the table
* Instead of 'unique_key' column we added non-unique 'key' column
  that can potentially be used for squashing delayed calls
  by scheduler itself (not implemented yet)
* Adjusted Scheduler implementation and tests accordingly
* Fixed task() YAQL function to work without precisely resolve
  task execution object in case it's called for the current
  task. Previously it was dependent on the luck and we were
  lucky enough that tests were passing.
* Increased length of 'unique_key' column for task executions to
  250 which is close to a limit for string fields participating
  in unique constraints.

Change-Id: Ib7aaa20c2c8834ab0f2d9c90457677c9edb62805

subject: Implementation of vlan-aware-vms for Linux Bridge
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-23 12:06:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/d2d387763442a26dcbef8f67eb404bf830d6b030', 'message': "[WIP]: vlan-aware-vms support for Linux Bridge

Implementation of vlan-aware-vms for linux bridge.

This adds an L2 agent extension for VLAN aware VMs and its
implementation for the Linux Bridge agent.

Whenever subports are required, the extension will create vlan
devices off of the parent port device following the same naming
scheme as normal ports. This allows the normal agent loop to see
these VLAN ports and wire them like any other port so the
extension doesn't have to concern itself with things like firewall
rules, anti-spoofing, or encapsulation onto the physical network.

Assumptions:
* A trunk object will be sent via RPC callbacks whenever a trunk
  or its subport memberships change.
* Something will implement the RPC callback listener for the pull
  interface for trunks.
* We resolve the issue of updating the host_id of all of the subports
  whenever the parent trunk port host_id is updated.

TODO:
* Figure out when segmentation_type validation happens.
* Tests for this patch.

Change-Id: I688d5b25885c1c3938185467b15502ccf65cf935
Partially-implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms

"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2016-07-31 15:14:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/0776f8df3f4fd5c81bd35569ef598ad2fe0770fb', 'message': "[WIP]: Implementation of vlan-aware-vms for linux bridge.

This is the start of the implementation of vlan-aware-vms
for Linux Bridge.

This is a heavy work in progress, but it seems to be the
bare minimum to try out the feature:

* get client extensions from I6fe1dbd81813fae234801a61c0e3d89f9e7c791e
* enable the 'trunk' service plugin
* make a port, turn it into a trunk, attach it to a VM (or boot a VM with it)
* add subports and configure your guest on the corresponding VLAN
* don't forget these subports have security groups so add allow rules!

Whenever subports are required, the linux bridge trunk driver
will create vlan devices off of the parent port device following
the same naming scheme as normal ports. This allows the normal
agent loop to see these VLAN ports and wire them like any other
port so the extension doesn't have to concern itself with things
like firewall rules, anti-spoofing, or encapsulation onto the
physical network.

TODO:
* Lots of notes inline of suboptimal things.
* Tests for this patch.

Partially-implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms
Change-Id: I688d5b25885c1c3938185467b15502ccf65cf935

This is the start of the implementation of vlan-aware-vms
for Linux Bridge.

This is a heavy work in progress, but it seems to be the
bare minimum to try out the feature:

* get client extensions from I6fe1dbd81813fae234801a61c0e3d89f9e7c791e
* enable the 'trunk' service plugin
* make a port, turn it into a trunk, attach it to a VM (or boot a VM with it)
* add subports and configure your guest on the corresponding VLAN
* don't forget these subports have security groups so add allow rules!

Whenever subports are required, the linux bridge trunk driver
will create vlan devices off of the parent port device following
the same naming scheme as normal ports. This allows the normal
agent loop to see these VLAN ports and wire them like any other
port so the extension doesn't have to concern itself with things
like firewall rules, anti-spoofing, or encapsulation onto the
physical network.

TODO:
* Lots of notes inline of suboptimal things.
* Tests for this patch.

Partially-implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms
Change-Id: I688d5b25885c1c3938185467b15502ccf65cf935

commit_message:
Implementation of vlan-aware-vms for Linux Bridge

This is the agent-side implementation of vlan-aware-vms for
the Linux Bridge agent. It implements the feature using
vlan subinterfaces.

Whenever subports are required, the linux bridge trunk driver
will create vlan devices off of the parent port device following
the same naming scheme as normal ports. This allows the normal
agent loop to see these VLAN ports and wire them like any other
port so the trunk logic doesn't have to concern itself with things
like firewall rules, anti-spoofing, or encapsulation onto the
physical network.

How to try:

* enable the Linux Bridge mech driver and install the Linux Bridge agent
* enable the 'trunk' service plugin
* make a port, turn it into a trunk, attach it to a VM (or boot a VM with it)
* add subports and configure your guest on the corresponding VLAN
* don't forget these subports have security groups so add allow rules!

Partially-implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms
Change-Id: I688d5b25885c1c3938185467b15502ccf65cf935

Clean imports in code

In some part in the code we import objects. In the Openstack style
guidelines they recommend to import only modules.

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#imports

Change-Id: I251a19736cf24a7ace40ea10371452f36c0b49b2

commit_message:
Compress test execution logs

The volume of logs we collect in CI jobs are extensive. This
patch ensures that the logs collected are compressed to reduce
the space taken in CI systems.

PYTHONUNBUFFERED is also set to ensure that the console log
from the CI jobs is recorded in the exact order of execution.

Change-Id: I867081cb1f263e554f7dbe02791a46c9d2cef60f
Related-Bug: #1620849
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_nova refs/changes/86/367886/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: PYTHONUNBUFFERED=1[testenv:func_logs] commands = bash -c 'mkdir -p {toxinidir}/logs' bash -c 'rsync --archive --verbose --ignore-errors /var/log/ /openstack/log/ {toxinidir}/logs/ || true' bash -c 'find "{toxinidir}/logs/" -type f | sed "p;s|$|.txt|" | xargs -n2 mv' bash -c 'command gzip --best --recursive "{toxinidir}/logs/"' # end of the run. This will not produce a false positive. Any {[testenv:func_logs]commands}# Ignore_errors is set to true so that the logs are collected at the # end of the run. This will not produce a false positive. Any # exception will be mark the run as failed and exit 1 after all of # the commands have been iterated through. ignore_errors = True {[testenv:func_logs]commands}
deleted_lines: # end of the run. This will not produce a failse positive. Any bash -c 'mkdir -p {toxinidir}/logs' bash -c 'rsync -av --ignore-errors /var/log/ /openstack/log/ {toxinidir}/logs/ || true' bash -c 'mkdir -p {toxinidir}/logs' bash -c 'rsync -av --ignore-errors /var/log/ /openstack/log/ {toxinidir}/logs/ || true'

commit_message:
Use heat devstack plugin

Now that heat is available as a devstack plugin, we should
use it. In-tree devstack code for heat is planned to be
removed soon[1].

And also, this patch remove `update_heat_policy` function
in devstack plugin. Because fetching global stack list is
already option to use in Magnum.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/317618/

Change-Id: Iab675da5ea8d02b3f7e71f6169c81724a0066858
Co-Authored-By: OTSUKA, Yuanying <yuanying@fraction.jp>

commit_message:
Clean imports in code

This patch set modifies lines which are importing objects
instead of modules. As per openstack import guide lines, user should
import modules in a file not objects.

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#imports

Change-Id: Ibb5fb8b0c48ee3243c16e44ad112808e1c0b765f

commit_message:
Add gate-tripleo-buildimage-overcloud-full-centos-7-nv to check

The experimental jobs for building tripleo overcloud images has been
passing for a while now. Lets move it up to the check queue as a
non-voting job.

Change-Id: I27b2715000fdfb9b3756b514cbedccda71ad967a
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
puppet-tripleo: remove puppet-manager-core core permissions

Historically, puppet-tripleo was a Puppet OpenStack project, but it
recently moved under TripleO stadium [1], so it makes sense to remove
core permissions on puppet-manager-core and puppet-manager-release, to
keep only tripleo-core.

[1] I4dbf15dc32b27ab8e54058445384887e4a97e0ba

Change-Id: Ic80f7d5d7fa07b72e8141dab7bef50b41a0038b6

commit_message:
Adding OSSN-0066

MongoDB guest instance allows any user to connect

Change-Id: I40b6aa68436b58e11099617abf61b9b64be71eef
Closes-Bug: #1507841
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/77/368077/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Mongodb guest instance allows any user to connect --- ### Summary ### when creating a new mongodb single instance or cluster the default setting in mongodb security.authorization was set as disabled. This resulted in no need to provide user credentials to connect to the mongo instance and perform read / write operations from any network that is attached on instance create. ### Affected Services / Software ### Trove, Liberty ### Discussion ### Mongodb contains a security config set within `mongo.conf` as follows: security: authorization: "enabled" When creating a new mongodb instance or cluster within Trove the `security` value was not populated resulting in mongodb adopting the default value of `disabled`. With security authorization disabled there would be no enforcement of user authentification, allowing users to connect and perform read/write data operations from any network that is attached on instance create. A fix was implemented within Mitaka and back ported to Liberty that addresses the problem by setting the authorization parameter to `enabled` when the argument `cluser_secure` is passed. ### Recommended Actions ### Operators that require new instances of mongodb to have security authorization, are required to pass the `cluser_secure` argument to the Trove CLI / API. ### Contacts / References ### Author: Luke Hinds, Red Hat This OSSN : https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OSSN/OSSN-0066 Original LaunchPad Bug : https://bugs.launchpad.net/trove/+bug/1507841 Mailing List : [Security] tag on openstack-dev@lists.openstack.org OpenStack Security Group : https://launchpad.net/~openstack-ossg

commit_message:
[placement] Add some tests ensuring unicode resource provider info

Add some gabbi tests which demonstrate that it is possible to create
and query a resource provider that has a name that is outside the
bounds of ascii. The tests using a 4byte wide utf-8 character are left
as xfails because not all installations of mysql will support it.

Also confirm that if a unicode characters (uri-encoded or not) in
the uuid part of a resource providers path will result in the
expected 404 and not explode.

Closes-Bug: #1621605
Change-Id: I3d906c3296aa28b595fcc23c448c1744972c319d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/88/365688/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: fixtures: - APIFixture defaults: request_headers: accept: application/json x-auth-token: admin tests: - name: post resource provider with snowman POST: /resource_providers request_headers: content-type: application/json data: name:  uuid: $ENVIRON['RP_UUID'] status: 201 response_headers: location: //resource_providers/[a-f0-9-]+/ - name: get that resource provider GET: $LOCATION response_json_paths: $.name:  - name: query by name GET: /resource_providers?name=%e2%98%83 response_json_paths: $.resource_providers[0].name:  - name: delete that one DELETE: /resource_providers/$ENVIRON['RP_UUID'] status: 204 # These next three are expected to fail on many mysql # installations. It works with the local in-RAM sqlite # test database. - name: four byte utf8 smiley xfail: true POST: /resource_providers request_headers: content-type: application/json data: name: "\U0001F601" uuid: $ENVIRON['RP_UUID'] status: 201 response_headers: location: //resource_providers/[a-f0-9-]+/ - name: get that wide resource provider xfail: true GET: $LOCATION response_json_paths: $.name: "\U0001F601" - name: query by wide name xfail: true GET: /resource_providers?name=%F0%9F%98%81 response_json_paths: $.resource_providers[0].name: "\U0001F601"

commit_message:
Corrects documentation typo

In oslo_messaging/_drivers/impl_rabbit.py, the documentation of
the Consumer class is the following: """Init the Publisher class
with the exchange_name, routing_key, type, durable auto_delete""".
This should be corrected by putting Consumer instead of Publisher.

Closes-Bug: 1623550

Change-Id: I77d09aeb1268ed79590a8b02ab5bf370f3b72caf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/66/370266/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Gnocchi identities created before Swift playbook

When Swift is used for Gnocchi storage we need to add the project
to which the Gnocchi service user is assigned to an exclude list for
Swift's telemetry middleware. That requires the Gnocchi identities
to be created before Swift playbook execution but Gnocchi service
install depends on an existing Swift service when it uses Swift
for storage. This change ensures that those identities exist before
Swift playbook execution.

Depends-On: If66fa8c3aa44d44019e3cedb5033ab83a65bd6ab
Depends-On: If4fa5c1c4401911057f99488694d74f5d83330a8
Change-Id: I0b6b53d5a4ad7423058c382160cc5009e0b3d866
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/31/366931/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - include: os-gnocchi-install.yml when: - gnocchi_storage_driver is defined - gnocchi_storage_driver == 'swift') vars: - gnocchi_identity_only=True

commit_message:
[DOCS] Added HAProxy example to Production environment document.

Updated openstack_user_config.yml.example file to include an
example of enabling HAProxy in the production environment.

Change-Id: I7014a4cba21c9787271a1e12529b7630662006f2
Closes-Bug: 1623204

commit_message:
ModalPanel component

* implements fixed-container css class
* implements ModalPanel component
* Validations list now fits the viewport height and
  uses scrollbar if validation list overflows
* Renders Modal in Portal, so it does not collide
  with other components

Implements: blueprint refactor-modals
Change-Id: I932face9fa06dc76fd71651cacb0e78346a189c4

with MAC Address(es) column in Nodes table

Implements: blueprint update-nodes-listing

commit_message:
Avoid circular references in Macro class

Just as we store a weakref to the stack in the Function class, we must
also do the same with the template in the Macro class. Otherwise we end
up with circular references that don't get cleaned up until the garbage
collector runs.

Change-Id: Ia615de961f52e9fc5ef90e0668720b42c864a605
Closes-Bug: #1623706

commit_message:
Add container logs to the build

Currently we don't have logs of what happened in the containers.
This commit uses the lxc_container_create ability to bind mount the
/var/log directory from the containers inside the host on
/var/log/{{ inventory_hostname}}.

Change-Id: I836517f6a0e27c9554c54f01713f54a2b6384782
Signed-off-by: Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe.evrard@rackspace.co.uk>

added_lines: lxc_container_bind_mounts: - host_directory: "/openstack/logs/{{ inventory_hostname }}" container_directory: "/var/log"

commit_message:
Puppet4 support: cluster module

Cherry-pick of changes:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/327038/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/356728/

This cherry-pick makes the cluster module Puppet4 compatible.
Running Puppet4 units tests using the module rabbitmq ref 5.3.1-mos-rc3
will fail, since there is an Puppet4 related error in the rabbitmq module.

Change-Id: I8d09c56b5d3dbc93b63f36c71d44064c6f0c8ffe
Related-Bug: 1586480

Cherry picking https://review.openstack.org/#/c/331791/ leads to
a lot of problems.

commit_message:
Puppet4 support: refactor vips

Cherry-pick of change https://review.openstack.org/#/c/326541/

The generate_vips function is refactored to work in pair
with the create_resources functions. It's much better for testing
and debugging.
Input data of the vurual ip definition is split into many parameters
and the generate vips function is tought to support the changed
interfacs as well as to work with Puppet4's undef values.

Change-Id: I5fca1efaddeda3a8324ee5ff3b97ae9291b4e0dc
Related-Bug: 1586480

added_lines: # [*bridge*] # (Required) Name of the bridge that has network # namespace with VIP connected to it.# [*ip*] # (Required) The IPv4 address to be configured in # dotted quad notation.# [*ns_veth*] # (Required) Name of network namespace side of # the veth pair. # # [*base_veth*] # (Required) Name of base system side of # the veth pair. # # [*gateway*] # Default route address. # Default: none # # [*iflabel*] # You can specify an additional label for your IP address here. # This label is appended to your interface name. # Defualt: ka # # [*cidr_netmask*] # The netmask for the interface in CIDR format. # Default: 24 # # [*ns*] # Name of network namespace. # Default: haproxy # # [*gateway_metric*] # The metric value of the default route. # # [*other_networks*] # Additional routes that should be added to this resource. # Routes will be added via value ns_veth. # Should be space separated list of networks in CIDR format. # # [*iptables_comment*] # Iptables comment to associate with rules. # # [*ns_iptables_start_rules*] # Iptables rules that should be # started along with IP in the namespace. # # [*ns_iptables_stop_rules*] # Iptables rules that should be # stopped along with IP in the namespace. # # [*also_check_interfaces*] # Network interfaces list (ex. NIC), that should be in # UP state for monitor action returns succesful. # # [*primitive_type*] # The name of the OCF script to use. # Default: ns_IPaddr2 # # [*use_pcmk_prefix*] # Should the 'p_' prefix be added to # commit_message:
Puppet4 support: l23network changes

Puppet4 changes from master branched rolled up into one change.
Plus change to osnailyfacter function nic_whitelist_to_json, since that
was part of an change in master.

Cherry-pick from changes:
324384
326543
326558
332178
326542
333570
356729
358794
363973
365028

Change-Id: I36ba2c86569a9ff4e607297b337ade282b1fd2b0
Related-Bug: 1586480

commit_message:
libvirt: Rewrite test_rescue and test_rescue_config_drive

This rewrite was primarily motivated by bug 1597669. We were testing
that we were creating disks, but not that they were being added to the
resulting domain.

Related-bug: #1597669
Change-Id: Ibe739b1811bdacad08a7fc499d26e4bed834eec9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/66/335966/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Some mocks to avoid hitting the DB @mock.patch.object(libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver, '_set_host_enabled', mock.Mock()) @mock.patch.object(libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver, '_build_device_metadata', mock.Mock(return_value=None)) @mock.patch('nova.api.metadata.base.InstanceMetadata', mock.MagicMock()) def _test_rescue(self, instance, disks, exists=None): network_info = _fake_network_info(self, 1) orig_create_domain = self.drvr._create_domain with test.nested( mock.patch.object(self.drvr, '_create_domain', side_effect=orig_create_domain), mock_backend(disks=disks, exists=exists) ) as (mock_create_domain, mock_ignored): self.drvr.rescue(self.context, instance, network_info, image_meta, rescue_password) # Get the generated domain XML by extracting it from the call to # _create_domain() mock_create_domain.assert_called_once() # call_args_list contains a tuple, the first entry of which is # *args (positional arguments) create_domain_args = mock_create_domain.call_args_list[0][0] # xml is the first positional argument to _create_domain() xml = create_domain_args[0] return etree.fromstring(xml) def test_rescue(self): instance = self._create_instance({'config_drive': None}) disks = {} doc = self._test_rescue(instance, disks) # Assert that we called cache() to create the expected set of disks, # and no others created = set([name for name, disk in six.iteritems(disks) if disk.cache.called]) self.assertEqual(set(['disk.rescue', 'kernel.rescue', 'ramdisk.rescue']), created) kernel_ramdisk = [disks[name + '.rescue'] for name in ('kernel', 'ramdisk')] # Assert that kernel and ramdisk were both created as raw for disk in kernel_ramdisk: self.assertEqual('raw', disk.image_type) # Assert that the root rescue disk was created as the default type self.assertEqual('default', disks['disk.rescue'].image_type) # We expect the generated domain to contain disk.rescue and # disk, in that order expected_domain_disk_paths = map( lambda name: disks[name].path, ('disk.rescue', 'disk')) domain_disk_paths = doc.xpath('devices/disk/source/@file') self.assertEqual(expected_domain_disk_paths, domain_disk_paths) # The generated domain xml should contain the rescue kernel # and ramdisk expected_kernel_ramdisk_paths = map( lambda disk: os.path.join(CONF.instances_path, disk.path), kernel_ramdisk) kernel_ramdisk_paths = \ doc.xpath('os/*[self::initrd|self::kernel]/text()') self.assertEqual(expected_kernel_ramdisk_paths, kernel_ramdisk_paths) def test_rescue_config_drive(self): instance = self._create_instance({'config_drive': str(True)}) disks = {} doc = self._test_rescue( instance, disks, exists=lambda name: name != 'disk.config.rescue') # Assert that we called cache() to create the expected set of disks, # and no others created = set([name for name, disk in six.iteritems(disks) if disk.cache.called]) self.assertEqual(set(['disk.rescue', 'kernel.rescue', 'ramdisk.rescue']), created) # Assert that we imported the config disk config_disk = disks['disk.config.rescue'] config_disk.import_file.assert_called_once() # Assert that the config disk, kernel and ramdisk were created as raw kernel_ramdisk = [disks[name + '.rescue'] for name in ('kernel', 'ramdisk')] for disk in [config_disk] + kernel_ramdisk: self.assertEqual('raw', disk.image_type) # Assert that the root rescue disk was created as the default type self.assertEqual('default', disks['disk.rescue'].image_type) # We expect the generated domain to contain disk.rescue, disk, and # config disk in that order # NOTE(mdbooth): But it doesn't! Config disk is missing. # See https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1597669 # For now we assert the broken behaviour as a # placeholder until the fix lands. expected_domain_disk_paths = map( lambda name: disks[name].path, ('disk.rescue', 'disk')) domain_disk_paths = doc.xpath('devices/disk/source/@file') self.assertEqual(expected_domain_disk_paths, domain_disk_paths) # The generated domain xml should contain the rescue kernel # and ramdisk expected_kernel_ramdisk_paths = map( lambda disk: os.path.join(CONF.instances_path, disk.path), kernel_ramdisk) kernel_ramdisk_paths = \ doc.xpath('os/*[self::initrd|self::kernel]/text()') self.assertEqual(expected_kernel_ramdisk_paths, kernel_ramdisk_paths)
deleted_lines: def test_rescue(self): instance = self._create_instance({'config_drive': None}) dummyxml = ("<domain type='kvm'><name>instance-0000000a</name>" "<devices>" "<disk type='file'><driver name='qemu' type='raw'/>" "<source file='/test/disk'/>" "<target dev='vda' bus='virtio'/></disk>" "<disk type='file'><driver name='qemu' type='qcow2'/>" "<source file='/test/disk.local'/>" "<target dev='vdb' bus='virtio'/></disk>" "</devices></domain>") network_info = _fake_network_info(self, 1) self.mox.StubOutWithMock(self.drvr, '_get_existing_domain_xml') self.mox.StubOutWithMock(libvirt_utils, 'write_to_file') self.mox.StubOutWithMock(self.drvr, '_get_guest_xml') self.mox.StubOutWithMock(self.drvr, '_destroy') self.mox.StubOutWithMock(self.drvr, '_create_domain') self.drvr._get_existing_domain_xml(mox.IgnoreArg(), mox.IgnoreArg()).MultipleTimes().AndReturn(dummyxml) libvirt_utils.write_to_file(mox.IgnoreArg(), mox.IgnoreArg()) self.drvr._get_guest_xml(mox.IgnoreArg(), instance, network_info, mox.IgnoreArg(), image_meta, rescue=mox.IgnoreArg(), write_to_disk=mox.IgnoreArg() ).AndReturn(dummyxml) self.drvr._destroy(instance) self.drvr._create_domain(mox.IgnoreArg(), post_xml_callback=mox.IgnoreArg()) self.mox.ReplayAll() disks = {} with mock_backend(disks=disks, exists=lambda name: name != 'disk.config.rescue'): self.drvr.rescue(self.context, instance, network_info, image_meta, rescue_password) self.mox.VerifyAll() self.assertEqual(3, len(disks)) expected_types = { 'kernel.rescue': 'raw', 'ramdisk.rescue': 'raw', 'disk.rescue': 'default' } # cache() should have been called on the 3 disk backends for name in ('kernel', 'ramdisk', 'disk'): name = name + '.rescue' disk = disks[name] self.assertTrue(disk.cache.called) self.assertEqual(expected_types[name], disk.image_type) @mock.patch( 'nova.virt.libvirt.driver.LibvirtDriver._build_device_metadata', return_value=None) @mock.patch( 'nova.virt.configdrive.ConfigDriveBuilder.add_instance_metadata') @mock.patch('nova.virt.configdrive.ConfigDriveBuilder.make_drive') @mock.patch('nova.virt.libvirt.guest.Guest') def test_rescue_config_drive(self, mock_guest, mock_make, mock_add, mock_save): instance = self._create_instance({'config_drive': str(True)}) uuid = instance.uuid configdrive_path = uuid + '/disk.config.rescue' dummyxml = ("<domain type='kvm'><name>instance-0000000a</name>" "<devices>" "<disk type='file'><driver name='qemu' type='raw'/>" "<source file='/test/disk'/>" "<target dev='vda' bus='virtio'/></disk>" "<disk type='file'><driver name='qemu' type='qcow2'/>" "<source file='/test/disk.local'/>" "<target dev='vdb' bus='virtio'/></disk>" "</devices></domain>") network_info = _fake_network_info(self, 1) self.mox.StubOutWithMock(self.drvr, '_get_existing_domain_xml') self.mox.StubOutWithMock(libvirt_utils, 'write_to_file') self.mox.StubOutWithMock(instance_metadata.InstanceMetadata, '__init__') self.mox.StubOutWithMock(self.drvr, '_get_guest_xml') self.mox.StubOutWithMock(self.drvr, '_destroy') self.drvr._get_existing_domain_xml(mox.IgnoreArg(), mox.IgnoreArg()).MultipleTimes().AndReturn(dummyxml) libvirt_utils.write_to_file(mox.IgnoreArg(), mox.IgnoreArg()) instance_metadata.InstanceMetadata.__init__(mox.IgnoreArg(), content=mox.IgnoreArg(), extra_md=mox.IgnoreArg(), network_info=mox.IgnoreArg()) image_meta = objects.ImageMeta.from_dict( {'id': uuids.image_id, 'name': 'fake'}) self.drvr._get_guest_xml(mox.IgnoreArg(), instance, network_info, mox.IgnoreArg(), image_meta, rescue=mox.IgnoreArg(), write_to_disk=mox.IgnoreArg() ).AndReturn(dummyxml) self.drvr._destroy(instance) self.mox.ReplayAll() rescue_password = 'fake_password' disks = {} with mock_backend(disks, exists=lambda name: name != 'disk.config.rescue'): self.drvr.rescue(self.context, instance, network_info, image_meta, rescue_password) self.mox.VerifyAll() mock_add.assert_any_call(mock.ANY) expected_call = [mock.call(os.path.join(CONF.instances_path, configdrive_path))] mock_make.assert_has_calls(expected_call) self.assertEqual(4, len(disks)) expected_types = { 'kernel.rescue': 'raw', 'ramdisk.rescue': 'raw', 'disk.rescue': 'default' } # cache() should have been called on the 3 non-config disk backends for name in ('kernel', 'ramdisk', 'disk'): name = name + '.rescue' disk = disks[name] self.assertTrue(disk.cache.called) self.assertEqual(expected_types[name], disk.image_type) self.assertEqual('raw', disks['disk.config.rescue'].image_type) # import_file() should have been called for the config disk self.assertTrue(disks['disk.config.rescue'].import_file.called)

commit_message:
Allows condition name using boolean or function

This change supports:
1. Allow boolean value or condition function as
   condition name of 'if' function:
   resources:
     r1:
        ...
	properties:
	  a: {if: [true, 'value_true', 'value_false']}
     r2:
       ...
       properties:
         b: {if: [{equals: [...]}, 'value_true', 'value_false']}
2. Allow boolean value or condition function as
   condtiion name in resource definition:
   resources:
     r1:
       ...
       condition: false
     r2:
       ...
       condition: {and: [cd1, cd2]}
3. Allow boolean value or condition function as
   condition name in outputs:
   outputs:
     output1:
       value: ...
       condition: true
     output2:
       value: ...
       condition: {not: cd3}

Change-Id: I2bf9bb0b608788c928d12425cbfdaf658df9e880
Co-Authored-By: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
Blueprint: support-conditions-function

added_lines: def test_if_using_boolean_condition(self): snippet = {'if': [True, 'value_if_true', 'value_if_false']} # when condition is true, if function resolve to value_if_true tmpl = template.Template(hot_newton_tpl_empty) stack = parser.Stack(utils.dummy_context(), 'test_if_using_boolean_condition', tmpl) resolved = self.resolve(snippet, tmpl, stack) self.assertEqual('value_if_true', resolved) # when condition is false, if function resolve to value_if_false snippet = {'if': [False, 'value_if_true', 'value_if_false']} resolved = self.resolve(snippet, tmpl, stack) self.assertEqual('value_if_false', resolved) def test_if_using_condition_function(self): tmpl_with_conditions = template_format.parse(''' heat_template_version: 2016-10-14 conditions: create_prod: False ''') snippet = {'if': [{'not': 'create_prod'}, 'value_if_true', 'value_if_false']} tmpl = template.Template(tmpl_with_conditions) stack = parser.Stack(utils.dummy_context(), 'test_if_using_condition_function', tmpl) resolved = self.resolve(snippet, tmpl, stack) self.assertEqual('value_if_true', resolved) exc = self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidConditionReference, self.assertIn('Invalid condition "cd_not_existing"',

subject: Implement scenario capability for AIO
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-13 14:24:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/7fa24d161e00e028050176a1addc772cfc91f5d9', 'message': 'Implement scenario capability for AIO

In order to prepare for the ability to implement multiple
integrated gate scenarios, this patch does the following:

- Ensures that all inventory groups are complete and can
  be entered into the inventory with their own host groups
  instead of being forced to use the shared-os-infra group.

- Splits all OpenStack service environment configurations
  into individual conf.d files so that scenarios can be
  selective about which services are deployed.

- Implements the ability to set the desired scenario via
  an environment variable. This has already been
  implemented in OpenStack-CI.

- The current AIO is set as the default scenario, and it
  is set even if there is no environment variable present.

Change-Id: I99541d36aed6d4b9f83746c1cd1a5521b310f1f6
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-09-13 14:35:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/e2aa25538751cc8106945d799f61d3b4ce567fb6', 'message': 'Implement scenario capability for AIO

In order to prepare for the ability to implement multiple
integrated gate scenarios, this patch does the following:

- Ensures that all inventory groups are complete and can
  be entered into the inventory with their own host groups
  instead of being forced to use the shared-os-infra group.

- Splits all OpenStack service environment configurations
  into individual conf.d files so that scenarios can be
  selective about which services are deployed.

- Implements the ability to set the desired scenario via
  an environment variable. This has already been
  implemented in OpenStack-CI.

- The current AIO is set as the default scenario, and it
  is set even if there is no environment variable present.

Change-Id: I99541d36aed6d4b9f83746c1cd1a5521b310f1f6

commit_message:
Implement scenario capability for AIO

In order to prepare for the ability to implement multiple
integrated gate scenarios, this patch does the following:

- Ensures that all inventory groups are complete and can
  be entered into the inventory with their own host groups
  instead of being forced to use the shared-os-infra group.

- Splits all OpenStack service environment configurations
  into individual conf.d files so that scenarios can be
  selective about which services are deployed.

- Implements the ability to set the desired scenario via
  an environment variable. This has already been
  implemented in OpenStack-CI.

- The current AIO is set as the default scenario, and it
  is set even if there is no environment variable present.

Depends-On: I5441f8f9a9c02cc0a501a9b9f7c6cbe2604f4b65
Change-Id: I99541d36aed6d4b9f83746c1cd1a5521b310f1f6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/85/369485/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - horizon_containers physical_skel: horizon_containers: belongs_to: - all_containers horizon_hosts: belongs_to: - hosts

commit_message:
Upgrade to Storm 1.0.2

Also, remove devstack/files/storm/cluster.xml. That file was for the
0.9.x version and it caused there to be no logging for supervisor and
nimbus

Change-Id: Iafcf40f4406ad7e6ddae20e51a5f21d6794c0607
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-api refs/changes/53/364453/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: STORM_VERSION=${STORM_VERSION:-1.0.2}

commit_message:
Stop using mox in unit/volume/drivers/*.py

As mox is not compatible with python 3, all test cases
that use mox should be updated to use mock instead.

Replaced stubs.Set() with mock_object() in some classes in
cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/.

Change-Id: I8c180d3d466cf4b9bb19e939bafaffd5c9b382de

commit_message:
Change the behavior of waiting process for wsrep_cluster_status.

Wsrep for kolla-kubernetes is not implemented yet.
This patch fixes waiting process of wsrep_cluster_status so that
kolla_security_reset can handle interactions.

Change-Id: I5c6bd6fc1df7829e6412b46a50509fb3918aa79a
Closes-Bug: #1623726
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/91/370491/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [[ ! "${!KOLLA_KUBERNETES[@]}" ]]; then set +e CLUSTER_READY=$(mysql -u root --exec="SHOW STATUS LIKE 'wsrep_cluster_status'" | grep Primary) TIMEOUT=${DB_MAX_TIMEOUT:-60} while [[ -z "${CLUSTER_READY}" ]]; do if [[ ${TIMEOUT} -gt 0 ]]; then let TIMEOUT-=1 sleep 1 else exit 1 fi done set -e else # KOLLA_KUBERNETES: Wait for a chunk of outputs of the mariadb server. sleep 3 fi
deleted_lines: CLUSTER_READY=$(mysql -u root --exec="SHOW STATUS LIKE 'wsrep_cluster_status'" | grep Primary) TIMEOUT=${DB_MAX_TIMEOUT:-60} while [[ -z "${CLUSTER_READY}" ]]; do if [[ ${TIMEOUT} -gt 0 ]]; then let TIMEOUT-=1 sleep 1 else exit 1 fi done

commit_message:
Check policy of resource type again

We allow to delete a stack which is in *_IN_PROGRESS state
and locked by other alive engine. There may be additional
resources that we don't know about if an update was
in-progress when the stack was stopped, so we reload the
stack from the database again before delete the stack, we
have to check the resource policy again in this case.

Change-Id: Id9d6d64f3179a18fedf80449d1e4ec8efae03e4e

commit_message:
Add tacker gerrit dashbaord to developer info

With too many gerrit reviews in the queue, the team
needs a way to categorize and bubble up reviews that
are actionable. Hence introduce gerrit dashboard with
various filters to identify patchsets to review.

Change-Id: I6e1552f8a3fbd81ae45ad1943b493e8c3bd83654

subject: LinuxBridge: Use ifindex for logical 'timestamp'
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-13 07:20:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/0bd227e705159dc3aaf449062c4948f476e5155a', 'message': "LinuxBridge: Use ifindex for logical 'timestamp'

With Xenial (and maybe older versions), the modified timestamps
in /sys/class/net/(device_name) are not stable. They appear to
work for a period of time, and then when some kind of cache clears
on the kernel side, all of the timestamps are reset to the latest
access time.

This was causing the Linux Bridge agent to think that the interfaces
were experiencing local changes much more frequently than they actually
were, resulting in more polling to the Neutron server and subsequently
more BUILD->ACTIVE->BUILD->ACTIVE transitions in the logical model.

The purpose of the timestamp patch was to catch rapid server REBUILD
operations where the interface would be deleted and re-added within
a polling interval. Without it, these would be stuck in the BUILD
state since the agent wouldn't realize it needed to wire the ports.

This patch switches to looking at the IFINDEX of the interfaces to
use as a sort of logical timestamp. If an interface gets removed
and readded, it will get a different index, so the original timestamp
comparison logic will still work.

In the future, the agent should undergo a larger refactor to just
watch 'ip monitor' for netlink events to replace the polling of the
interface listing and the timestamp logic entirely. However, this
approach was taken due to the near term release and the ability to
back-port it to older releases.

This was verified with both Nova rebuild actions and Nova interface
attach/detach actions.

Change-Id: I016019885446bff6806268ab49cd5476d93ec61f
Closes-Bug: #1622833

commit_message:
LinuxBridge: Use ifindex for logical 'timestamp'

With Xenial (and maybe older versions), the modified timestamps
in /sys/class/net/(device_name) are not stable. They appear to
work for a period of time, and then when some kind of cache clears
on the kernel side, all of the timestamps are reset to the latest
access time.

This was causing the Linux Bridge agent to think that the interfaces
were experiencing local changes much more frequently than they actually
were, resulting in more polling to the Neutron server and subsequently
more BUILD->ACTIVE->BUILD->ACTIVE transitions in the logical model.

The purpose of the timestamp patch was to catch rapid server REBUILD
operations where the interface would be deleted and re-added within
a polling interval. Without it, these would be stuck in the BUILD
state since the agent wouldn't realize it needed to wire the ports.

This patch switches to looking at the IFINDEX of the interfaces to
use as a sort of logical timestamp. If an interface gets removed
and readded, it will get a different index, so the original timestamp
comparison logic will still work.

In the future, the agent should undergo a larger refactor to just
watch 'ip monitor' for netlink events to replace the polling of the
interface listing and the timestamp logic entirely. However, this
approach was taken due to the near term release and the ability to
back-port it to older releases.

This was verified with both Nova rebuild actions and Nova interface
attach/detach actions.

Change-Id: I016019885446bff6806268ab49cd5476d93ec61f
Closes-Bug: #1622833

When creating many containers on a single contended host,
the execution of many delegated tasks in parallel results
in false results coming back from ansible.

This patch consolidates the networking tasks into a
single task which is executed via a script which is
placed into the container via the host's process for
the container.

This appears to be more reliable, even under contention.

Change-Id: I0823e34286a0857b539a94604dbe9cdeb8a605f0
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Change the container prep using more intelligent commands

When creating many containers on a single contended host, the execution
of many delegated tasks in parallel results in failure. This patch
consolidates the container prep and networking tasks leveraging the
lxc-rootfs pid path on the physical host instead of relying on delegation.

Change-Id: I0823e34286a0857b539a94604dbe9cdeb8a605f0
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_container_create refs/changes/20/354120/18 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env bash set -ev # Generate the lxc container create prep commands {{ lxc_container_map.prep_commands }} {{ lxc_container_commands }} {% for item in lxc_container_bind_mounts %} {% if item['container_directory'] is defined %} [[ ! -d "{{ item['container_directory'] }}" ]] && mkdir -p "{{ item['container_directory'] }}" {% endif %} {% endfor %} {% if container_networks is defined and container_networks %} {% for item in container_networks.iteritems() %} echo -e '{{ lxc_container_interface }}' | tee {{ lxc_container_interface_target }} {% if item.value is defined %} {% if item.value.static_routes is defined %} echo -e '{{ lxc_container_default_route_interfaces.route_setup }}' | tee {{ lxc_container_default_route_interfaces.route_file }} {% endif %} {% endif %} {% endfor %} {% endif %}

commit_message:
Refactor resource definition parsing in HOT/cfn

Parse each field in a resource definition individually instead of all in
one go. This allows the HOT and cfn formats to apply different parsing to
different fields - specifically in the future we want to parse the
condition field like a condition, using only the valid condition functions.

Change-Id: I5b864d241a5e16c09fcce30c40d634d9bb72e173
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/52/368352/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from heat.engine.hot import templatefrom heat.engine import rsrc_defn class HOTInterpreter(template.HOTemplate20150430): def __new__(cls): return object.__new__(cls) def __init__(self): version = {'heat_template_version': '2015-04-30'} super(HOTInterpreter, self).__init__(version) def parse(self, stack, snippet, path=''): return snippet def parse_conditions(self, stack, snippet, path=''): return snippet def _get_resource_definition(self): resource_def = self.properties[self.RESOURCE] defn_data = dict(HOTInterpreter()._rsrc_defn_args(None, 'member', resource_def)) return rsrc_defn.ResourceDefinition(None, **defn_data)
deleted_lines: from heat.engine import template def _get_resource_definition(self, template_version=('heat_template_version', '2015-04-30')): tmpl = template.Template(dict([template_version])) return tmpl.rsrc_defn_from_snippet(None, self.properties[self.RESOURCE])

commit_message:
Add ansible role for vmtp container

Add vmtp ansible role to kolla.

Co-Authored-By: Larry Rensing <lr699s@att.com>
Co-Authored-By: Tin Lam <tinlam@gmail.com>
Partially implements: bp vmtp-container

Change-Id: Ib3945e0a94cca9f3a8c4f55953b40674c88ac8e4

"}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2016-06-27 08:03:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/157a3b82ac3a7eeb62fd238d49f19409c74dc0a9', 'message': "Correct floating IP updating issues

Know issues:
1. Updating floating IP extra attributes, for instance description,
will unexpectedly disassociate it. This will interrupt the user's
service traffic.
2. If user try to update floating IP extra attribute with port_id
that it associated with, the neutron API will return a bad request
exception.
So there is no way to update the floating IP extra attributes without
changing it's association.

This patch will make this work properly, after this patch, an explicit
`null` port_id will be required when user try to disassociate floating
IP from a port.

Closes-Bug: #1578523
Change-Id: I036e473118431856550249359a22445380ef9ece
"}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2016-06-28 06:39:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/2e13b7ac93c640ab7f8e3a3b1f35e0337a4ca973', 'message': "Correct floating IP updating issues

Know issues:
1. Updating floating IP extra attributes, for instance description,
will unexpectedly disassociate it. This behavior will interrupt the
user's service traffic. And this is because that user can submit an
empty request dict (without port_id parameter) for the floating IP
updating API, and then it will be disassociated by default.
2. If user try to update floating IP extra attribute with port_id
that it associated with, the neutron API will return a bad request
exception.
So there is no way to update the floating IP extra attributes without
changing it's association.

This patch will make this work properly. After this patch, the following
behaviors will be made:
1. An explicit `null` port_id will be required when user try to
disassociate floating IP from a port.
2. Any floating IP updating request without port_id will not change its
association status anymore.
3. Any floating IP updating request with its original port_id, API will
do nothing and retrun no error.

APIImpact

Closes-Bug: #1578523
Change-Id: I036e473118431856550249359a22445380ef9ece
"}, {'number': 14, 'created': '2016-07-09 12:14:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/5292fd6dbec685796cbcead43318dfa38713d461', 'message': "Correct floating IP updating issues

Know issues:
1. Updating floating IP extra attributes, for instance description,
will unexpectedly disassociate it. This behavior will interrupt the
user's service traffic. And this is because that user can submit an
empty request dict (without port_id parameter) for the floating IP
updating API, and then it will be disassociated by default.
2. If user try to update floating IP extra attribute with port_id
that it associated with, the neutron API will return a bad request
exception.
So there is no way to update the floating IP extra attributes without
changing it's association.

This patch will make this work properly. After this patch, the following
behaviors will be made:
1. An explicit `null` port_id will be required when user try to
disassociate floating IP from a port.
2. Any floating IP updating request without port_id will not change its
association status anymore.
3. Any floating IP updating request with its original port_id, API will
not change the association, and retrun no error.

APIImpact

Closes-Bug: #1578523
Change-Id: I036e473118431856550249359a22445380ef9ece

commit_message:
Correct floating IP extra attributes updating issues

Updating floating IP extra attributes, for instance description,
will unexpectedly disassociate it. This behavior will interrupt the
user's service traffic. And this is because that user can submit an
empty request dict (without port_id parameter) for the floating IP
updating API, and then it will be disassociated by default.
So there is no way to update the floating IP extra attributes without
changing it's association.

This patch will make updating floating IP extra attributes API works
properly.

Closes-Bug: #1607746
Change-Id: I036e473118431856550249359a22445380ef9ece
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/49/312849/28 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _get_fip_internal_data(self, context, fip, floating_network_id): return internal_ip_address, router_id def _get_assoc_data(self, context, fip, floating_network_id): internal_ip_address, router_id = self._get_fip_internal_data( context, fip, floating_network_id) floating_network_id = floatingip_db['floating_network_id'] floating_network_id) if (port_id and floatingip_db.fixed_port_id and port_id == floatingip_db.fixed_port_id): # Floating IP association is not changed. return port_id, internal_ip_address, router_id floating_network_id=floating_network_id, net_id=floating_network_id) if 'port_id' not in fip and floatingip_db.fixed_port_id: # Update floating IP extra attributes do not change its association fip['port_id'] = floatingip_db.fixed_port_id internal_ip_address, router_id = self._get_fip_internal_data( context, fip, floating_network_id) port_id = floatingip_db.fixed_port_id

commit_message:
Refactor for floating IP updating checks

1. Will not fill the API fip updating dict with tenant_id and id
anymore, floatingip_db will be passed around functions.
We need to make the `fip` dict come from the API as it orginal is.

2. Refactor some redundant log messages for fip's port tenant_id
check and IP version check.

Change-Id: Ic45c95d90f3aecfcb731453fb3fd62e6ed92893b
Partial-bug: #1607746
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/46/369846/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _internal_fip_assoc_data(self, context, fip, tenant_id): if not internal_port['tenant_id'] == tenant_id: msg = (_('Cannot process floating IP association with ' 'Port %s, since that port is owned by a ' 'different tenant.') % port_id) msg = (_('Cannot process floating IP association with %s, ' 'since that is not an IPv4 address.') % internal_ip_address) def _get_assoc_data(self, context, fip, floatingip_db): internal_ip_address) = self._internal_fip_assoc_data( context, fip, floatingip_db['tenant_id']) router_id = self._get_router_for_floatingip( context, internal_port, internal_subnet_id, floatingip_db['floating_network_id']) floatingip_db)
deleted_lines: def _internal_fip_assoc_data(self, context, fip): if not internal_port['tenant_id'] == fip['tenant_id']: if 'id' in fip: floatingip_id = fip['id'] data = {'port_id': port_id, 'floatingip_id': floatingip_id} msg = (_('Port %(port_id)s is associated with a different ' 'tenant than Floating IP %(floatingip_id)s and ' 'therefore cannot be bound.') % data) else: msg = (_('Cannot create floating IP and bind it to ' 'Port %s, since that port is owned by a ' 'different tenant.') % port_id) if 'id' in fip: data = {'floatingip_id': fip['id'], 'internal_ip': internal_ip_address} msg = (_('Floating IP %(floatingip_id)s is associated ' 'with non-IPv4 address %(internal_ip)s and ' 'therefore cannot be bound.') % data) else: msg = (_('Cannot create floating IP and bind it to %s, ' 'since that is not an IPv4 address.') % internal_ip_address) def _get_assoc_data(self, context, fip, floating_network_id): internal_ip_address) = self._internal_fip_assoc_data(context, fip) router_id = self._get_router_for_floatingip(context, internal_port, internal_subnet_id, floating_network_id) floatingip_db['floating_network_id']) fip['tenant_id'] = floatingip_db['tenant_id'] fip['id'] = id

commit_message:
Migrate to using osc-lib

This new library provides the common logic used by openstack
clients. Replacing the imports from openstackclient and cliff.

Depends-On-External: https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/2088/
Depends-On: I095209c241876c6ab48595962e07144fc5cc34a6
Closes-Bug: #1620964
Change-Id: I103a13ff6c0af94b82f5e48652380adfbf331d34
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/60/335460/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: from cliff import commandfrom openstackclient.common import exceptions as oscexc from openstackclient.common import utils as osc_utils from openstackclient.i18n import _

commit_message:
Fix order of arguments in assertEqual

Some tests used incorrect order assertEqual(observed, expected).

The correct order expected by testtools is
assertEqual(expected, observed).

Change-Id: Ie6e999cb95c7c0d19e06cf94f7bbb6e5b1203ccf
Partial-Bug: #1259292

commit_message:
Added config option to enable SSL

Added option, osapi_volume_use_ssl, to the Cinder configuration that restores
its capability of utilizing SSL to encrypt the traffic to and from
the endpoint.

Change-Id: I6ecd6eda1eb0300e53b3088cd36c7e22dc79240d
Closes-Bug: 1590901

commit_message:
Clean imports in code

This patch set modifies lines which are importing objects
instead of modules in designate/scheduler/*.
As per open-stack import guide lines, user should
import modules in a file not objects.

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#imports

Change-Id: Ie843800c18e8d236b0cff4192504592b060c1ee3

commit_message:
Allow full searchlight response through Horizon

The Horizon REST API service is only letting the hits
portion of the response come through. This is a
problem for two reasons:

One, aggregations can't come through.
Two, It creates a difference between CORS
requests to searchlight and horizon requests to searchlight.

Change-Id: I06575e421868a089be17d3e16c81980880e21fcd
Closes-Bug: #1623101
Closes-Bug: #1623146
Partially-Closes-Bug: #1617327

commit_message:
Remove the lowercase case boolean type in heat param_type

heat-api had already return the boolean type using 'Boolean' in this commit:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/116762/ , So remove the lowercase case.

Change-Id: If2fd981ffb854699301b77c6b0bc318a90c178dc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/40/368440/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: elif param_type == 'Boolean':
deleted_lines: # heat-api currently returns the boolean type in lowercase # (see https://bugs.launchpad.net/heat/+bug/1361448) # so for better compatibility both are checked here elif param_type in ('Boolean', 'boolean'):

commit_message:
Cleanup the test settings

Karma and coverage tests scatter its result around.
And recently, infra team seems to set a subdirectory called
'cover' for coverage tests by default.

This patch accumulates their results into 'cover' subdirectory.

Change-Id: I9c32da1ffdbb2f3104d9ecd6303f1f92fc0fcda8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum-ui refs/changes/02/370502/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: dir: '../cover/karma/'

commit_message:
Do not process additional fields in search response

API can return additional fields in the search response data.
Search fails in this case with exception from the client.
This patch adds code that ignores processing of these fields,
additional information redirects to debug log.

Closes-Bug: #1621061
Change-Id: I749057d217518447cb24f9727a883e2cb148218a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-searchlightclient refs/changes/56/366756/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update Ironic playbook inclusion for tftp network

This change makes it possible for the ironic role to consume an
existing tftp network by appropriately setting the server address
and allowing the containers to automatically be assigned a nic
and address where appropriate. To illustrate how a tftp network
can be setup an example network configuration entry was added to
the openstack_user_config and interfaces aio files.

Depends-On: Id9f94c0238ad3b6598044fe618f9913e88acec8c
Depends-On: Ibfeba53c2be802c51a3edc386e50fcbab8d0b01b
Depends-On: I9861de0a0384661a27f0971f77ab340f4c1d59e3
Change-Id: I4dd57a2723ac0cc1cdbfcf7a0b94b98026d20c4a
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
standardize release note page ordering

In order to support automatically updating the release notes when we
create stable branches, we want the pages to be in a standard order.
This patch updates the order to be reverse chronological, so the most
recent notes appear at the top.

Change-Id: Ib364dcc8eb31275a31c83b68d7914263b183e393
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

subject: Do str_replace in a single pass
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-15 18:01:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/72d3e99957b027defa17156af2f8a1c1117eb145', 'message': 'Do str_replace in a single pass

calling str.replace(), with the result that some text could be subject to
multiple substitutions (i.e. some new text that was inserted by a
replacement could itself be partly replaced if some part of it matched
another key), although users could not rely on this happening since the
replacement order is explicitly undefined.

We anticipated that users would guard against problems here using some sort
of guard characters like %replace_me% (although we avoided requiring any
particular choice of characters). Over time it has become clear that for a
variety of reasons (of varying legitimacy), this is often not the case.
Sometimes the format of the source data is not under the direct control of
the user.

This patch revises the algorithm to perform the replacements in a single
pass. It also refactors the various version of the function so that we no
longer need two implementations of the core algorithm.

commit_message:
Do str_replace in a single pass

Previously we implemented the str_replace intrinsic function by repeatedly
calling str.replace(), with the result that some text could be subject to
multiple substitutions (i.e. some new text that was inserted by a
replacement could itself be partly replaced if some part of it matched
another key), although users could not rely on this happening since the
replacement order is explicitly undefined.

We anticipated that users would guard against problems here using some sort
of guard characters like %replace_me% (although we avoided requiring any
particular choice of characters). Over time it has become clear that for a
variety of reasons (of varying legitimacy), this is often not the case.
Sometimes the format of the source data is not under the direct control of
the user.

This patch revises the algorithm to perform the replacements in a single
pass and makes the ordering of keys deterministic. It also refactors the
various versions of the function so that we no longer need two
implementations of the core algorithm.

Change-Id: I43461a0d78226f921018efb32aae6e2255928bd0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/83/355583/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: def test_str_replace_order(self, tpl=hot_tpl_empty): tmpl = template.Template(tpl) def test_str_replace_liberty_order(self): """Test str_replace function substitution order.""" self.test_str_replace_order(hot_liberty_tpl_empty)

commit_message:
Serve the ceilometer-api using mod_wsgi

With the dependent change merged Ceilometer API will no longer run
without a stand-alone wsgi engine. It is too late in the cycle right
now to bring over changes for nginx and/or uwsgi for this project so
only this deployment option is being supported at this time.

Change-Id: I3cff6b183feae3c346cd56602d7b733a6dd9a01b
Depends-On: I8812ea1a92d6dc7f41a490e971bb7a09dee9b304

subject: More conservative allocation updates
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-07 17:09:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/40903ae8480fce84e217a4580a499fc425d934f2', 'message': 'More conservative allocation updates

This patch makes us query the existing allocations for a given instance

commit_message:
More conservative allocation updates

This patch makes us query the existing allocations for a given instance
before we send them, and avoid re-sending them if they are unchanged.

Co-Authored-By: Chris Dent <cdent@anticdent.org>
Change-Id: Ic75bd9d216be0264e048cebbcbf42b258c6687dc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/72/366872/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _get_allocations_for_instance(self, compute_node, instance): url = '/resource_providers/%s/allocations' % compute_node.uuid resp = self.get(url) if not resp: return {} else: return resp.json()['allocations'].get(instance.uuid, {}) my_allocations = self._allocations(instance) current_allocations = self._get_allocations_for_instance(compute_node, instance) if current_allocations == my_allocations: allocstr = ','.join(['%s=%s' % (k, v) for k, v in my_allocations.items()]) LOG.debug('Instance %(uuid)s allocations are unchanged: %(alloc)s', {'uuid': instance.uuid, 'alloc': allocstr}) return 'resources': my_allocations,

commit_message:
Support deployment of extra ceph.conf files

Currently, ceph_client role only deploys one ceph.conf
file to a hard-coded location of /etc/ceph/ceph.conf

Cinder is able to utilize multiple configs for Ceph
when using multiple Ceph clusters by defining the
variable rbd_ceph_conf in each rbd backend defined in
cinder_backends.

This patch allows a deployer to define the dictionary
variable ceph_extra_confs to deploy more ceph.conf files.

Change-Id: I1e8d1c6bb10915789ab4d08b5596844f01d2b8d7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-ceph_client refs/changes/31/370431/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Extra client configuration files ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Deployers can specify extra Ceph configuration files to support multiple Ceph cluster backends via the ``ceph_extra_confs`` variable. .. code-block:: console ceph_extra_confs: - src: "/opt/rdb-1.conf" dest: "/etc/ceph/rdb-1.conf" - src: "/opt/rdb-2.conf" dest: "/etc/ceph/rdb-2.conf" These config file sources must be present on the deployment host.

commit_message:
Fix container destroy host group

Containers were not being destroyed previously
as the host group in the destroy_containers play
had a typo and did not match any hosts

commit_message:
Install required packages in identity only mode

When in gnocchi_identity_only mode we need to have the keystone
module available which requires installing some members of
gnocchi_required_pip_packages and related distro packages.

We must ensure that we don't cause anything that causes a notify to
trigger service restarts however or the role execution will fail
later as it is not fully configured.

Change-Id: If66fa8c3aa44d44019e3cedb5033ab83a65bd6ab

commit_message:
Fix proprietary regression in py_pkgs.py

The change backports the newton version of the lookup plugin into mitaka
to resolve a regression where the proprietary package listings are being
indexed by the lookup plugin.

This is a combined backport as a clean backport from
"7af6721b4520ee96209e482bd66247afcfa7b4e5" is not possible.

Closes-Bug: 1622275
Depends-On: I6b0ae96ccf0f774be1c8a19374fbca295bb40a3b
Change-Id: I79f408dcee81ef59432e943bfc5e81644e3003b9
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Doc: Update PCI configuration options

- Add more explanations of JSON keys.
- pci_alias is used by nova-api not nova-compute.
- device_id is not valid.  Replaced with vendor_id.

Change-Id: I3547f36e9f1bcede433d2ae034086fb0686c781d

["vendor_id": "<id>",] ["product_id": "<id>",] "devname": "<name>",] {"<tag>": "<tag_value>",} Where '[' indicates zero or one occurrences, '{' indicates zero or multiple fields are automatically wildcarded. Supported <tag>: "physical_network". Valid examples are:

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-14 21:05:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-repo_build/commit/859be69534c5be28a9b538e335cd34757ea5051f', 'message': 'Update py_pkgs output data for updated lookup plugin

This patch adds the current master branch lookup results from

commit_message:
Update py_pkgs output data for updated lookup plugin

This patch adds the current master branch lookup results from
the following patches to validate that the lookup does not
break the existing build and to provide a sample set of data:

- https://review.openstack.org/370420

Related-Bug: 1622275
Needed-By: I79f408dcee81ef59432e943bfc5e81644e3003b9
Change-Id: I6b0ae96ccf0f774be1c8a19374fbca295bb40a3b

commit_message:
Journal recovery for basic scenarios

Recover failed entries that have basic handling such as created
resources that already exist, deleted resources that dont exist and
deleted resources that should be retried.

Change-Id: I637346ebea94fef064ad5af549847674c310fee1
Partially-implements: blueprint journal-recovery
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/19/358319/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from networking_odl.journal import recovery self._maintenance_thread.register_operation(recovery.journal_recovery)

commit_message:
unbreak test_l3_odl failure

Neutron changeset of dd5976b7ab62ef2c75a3ca76d7ab53dcbc988f51
change id of I8775aa8a477191ef21e7c3c6da31d098befefc3c
adds 'project_id' to returned value.
It borke some tests of test_l3_odl due to value change.
This patch adds 'project_id' key to unbreak it.

Change-Id: I3d53e10d0c96971fc002ff5a58431137688c52eb
Closes-Bug: #1623689

subject: Convert allNodesConfig properties to composable jinja2
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-05 22:18:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/83c372ddf92bf50f921fe04ecfd403f6cd9aa5fb', 'message': 'Convert allNodesConfig properties to composable jinja2

commit_message:
write docs about enabling kerberos

Change-Id: Ifc5a0edb4a2201708fecd085f4f9863c01d4cff5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/16/368716/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Enabling Kerberos security for cluster -------------------------------------- If you want to protect your clusters using MIT Kerberos security you have to complete few steps below. * If you would like to create a cluster protected by Kerberos security you need just to enable Kerberos by checkbox in the ``General Parameters`` section of the cluster configuration. If you prefer to use OpenStack CLI for cluster creation, you have put the data below in ``cluster_configs`` section: .. sourcecode:: console "cluster_configs": { "Enable Kerberos Security": true, } In this case, sahara will correctly prepare KDC server, will create principals along with keytabs to have an ability of authentication for Hadoop services. * Ensure that you have latest hadoop-openstack jar file distributed on your cluster nodes. You can pick one at ``http://tarballs.openstack.org/sahara/dist/`` * Sahara will create principals along with keytabs for system users like ``hdfs`` and ``spark`` so that you will not have to perform additional auth operations to execute your jobs on top of the cluster.

commit_message:
Alter nullable constraint on created_at column

oslo_db takes care of populating 'created_at' column with valid data
at the time of inserting record so it's guaranteed that 'created_at'
column will be never null. So there is no need of 'nullable=false'
for it.

This patch alters the nullable constraint from 'False' to 'True' for
existing hosts and failover_segments table by adding a new migration
script.

Closes-Bug: #1623526

Change-Id: I9ce46b43796b790c318e244d722ac0825e36c1cc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/masakari refs/changes/48/370148/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from sqlalchemy import MetaData, Table def upgrade(migrate_engine): meta = MetaData(bind=migrate_engine) failover_segments = Table('failover_segments', meta, autoload=True) hosts = Table('hosts', meta, autoload=True) for table in [failover_segments, hosts]: table.c.created_at.alter(nullable=True)

commit_message:
Add notification db apis and migration script

Added notifications related db apis and migration script.
Masakari operator has to sync the database with masakari-manage
command to create 'notifications' table in database.

Change-Id: Id863a3fc07145536fa449947205d375c777be3d7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/masakari refs/changes/76/367976/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2016 NTT Data. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from migrate.changeset import UniqueConstraint from sqlalchemy import Column, MetaData, Table from sqlalchemy import Integer, DateTime, String, Enum, Text def define_notifications_table(meta): notifications = Table('notifications', meta, Column('created_at', DateTime), Column('updated_at', DateTime), Column('deleted_at', DateTime), Column('deleted', Integer), Column('id', Integer, primary_key=True, nullable=False), Column('notification_uuid', String(36), nullable=False), Column('generated_time', DateTime, nullable=False), Column('source_host_id', String(36), nullable=False), Column('type', Enum('COMPUTE_HOST', 'VM', 'PROCESS', name='notifications_type'), nullable=False), Column('payload', Text), Column('status', Enum('new', 'running', 'error', 'failed', 'ignored', 'finished', name='notifications_status'), nullable=False), UniqueConstraint('notification_uuid', name='uniq_notifications0uuid'), mysql_engine='InnoDB', mysql_charset='utf8', extend_existing=True) return notifications def upgrade(migrate_engine): meta = MetaData() meta.bind = migrate_engine table = define_notifications_table(meta) table.create()

commit_message:
Move NoActionRequired exception back where it belongs

It makes no sense for an exception that is used for local flow control -
especially flow control between the Resource superclass and its
subclasses - to be defined in the heat.common.exceptions module where
user-facing exceptions whose definitions must be shared between the engine
and api are defined.

This patch moves it back to the original, correct location and adds
docstrings so people will actually know what it's for.

Technically both this and the original move were breaking changes to the
third-party Resource plugin API. This exception seems much less likely to
be in widespread use than UpdateReplace (c.f. preceding patch) though.

This reverts commit 5120f096d7ef8d14c6a0d763659d4c51d1f00345.

Change-Id: I73dc671cd7e6e37ecb0f13545c7fa93d58e6e8ff
Related-Bug: #1611104
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/24/352624/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-14 15:38:24.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/common/utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/294c5a11ca6dc61d2cd873e6460a1b39a256a9c4', 'message': "Remove unused read_cached_file method from utils

The read_cached_file() method in keystone.common.utils isn't being
used anywhere in keystone and it isn't tested. Let's remove it.

Change-Id: Iafba37114957c5270351aafd25538c6085c07805
"}]
commit_message:
Remove unused read_cached_file method from utils

The read_cached_file() method in keystone.common.utils isn't being
used anywhere in keystone and it isn't tested. Let's remove it.

Change-Id: Iafba37114957c5270351aafd25538c6085c07805
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/28/370228/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def read_cached_file(filename, cache_info, reload_func=None): """Read from a file if it has been modified. :param cache_info: dictionary to hold opaque cache. :param reload_func: optional function to be called with data when file is reloaded due to a modification. :returns: data from file. """ mtime = os.path.getmtime(filename) if not cache_info or mtime != cache_info.get('mtime'): with open(filename) as fap: cache_info['data'] = fap.read() cache_info['mtime'] = mtime if reload_func: reload_func(cache_info['data']) return cache_info['data']

subject: Remove unused _convert_to_integers() method
revisions:

This method isn't used anywhere and isn't tested.

Change-Id: Ibb30798827b0fb94c7c84f41f1d16300fe2fd7bb

commit_message:
Remove unused _convert_to_integers() method

This method isn't used anywhere and isn't tested.

Change-Id: Ibb30798827b0fb94c7c84f41f1d16300fe2fd7bb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/05/370305/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def _convert_to_integers(self, id_value): """Cast user and group system identifiers to integers.""" # NOTE(lbragstad) os.chown() will raise a TypeError here if # keystone_user_id and keystone_group_id are not integers. Let's cast # them to integers if we can because it's possible to pass non-integer # values into the fernet_setup utility. try: id_int = int(id_value) except ValueError as e: msg = _LE('Unable to convert Keystone user or group ID. Error: %s') LOG.error(msg, e) raise return id_int

'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-08-16 16:01:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/d05e31116f4d0d11a55985f57425234444c3e25a', 'message': "Corrections for the API specifications in api-ref

Fixes a number of technical issues with the api-ref section
including:

- Added missing headers
- The header descriptions were made specific to whether they
  are used in requests or responses and the verb in question
  (example: Content-Length in object HEAD is the object size,
  not the response body length).
- Added references to API features such as bulk delete.
- Many typographical fixes (e.g., spaces in the middle
  of header names)
- Restored xml and json account/container listing
  examples.

The following areas were not updated and it is proposed
to defer them to a subsequent update. This is because
I don't have time or their merit is debatable:

- ACLs (as used in a Keystone context) are not
  described.
- Account create/delete is not described.
- I left List Endpoints as-is.

Change-Id: I315b4e550b7d10880fbc00fce9311127ba609c2d

commit_message:
Corrections for the API specifications in api-ref

Fixes a number of technical issues with the api-ref section
including:

- Added missing headers
- The header descriptions were made specific to whether they
  are used in requests or responses and the verb in question
  (example: Content-Length in object HEAD is the object size,
  not the response body length).
- Added references to API features such as bulk delete.
- Many typographical fixes (e.g., spaces in the middle
  of header names)
- Restored xml and json account/container listing
  examples.

The following areas were not updated and it is proposed
to defer them to a subsequent update. This is because
I don't have time or their merit is debatable:

- ACLs (as used in a Keystone context) are not
  described.
- Account create/delete is not described.
- I left List Endpoints as-is.

Change-Id: I315b4e550b7d10880fbc00fce9311127ba609c2d

commit_message:
Unity: Use job for NFS share creation

This patch consolidates NFS file system creation
and share creation in one rest call.

Change-Id: I513ec9d4bd54e9c741caed4e94e115b0fe44dd0f
Closes-bug: #1618824

commit_message:
Don't add dhcp provisioning blocks if IP same

There is no purpose waiting for the DHCP agent to report back
if the fixed IPs for a port didn't actually change on a port
update.

Closes-Bug: #1622783
Change-Id: Ib17f41a444a53bf094cac1718568866df905d8ca

subject: Fix error when the git folder contains broken symlinks
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-14 21:34:23.000000000', 'files': ['tasks/repo_post_install.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-repo_server/commit/0eba29b2e0e4e1d779e526e9f9d594820d6bc2cd', 'message': 'Fix error when the git folder contains broken symlinks

When the git repository folder contains symbolic links pointing to non
existant files, the task would fail because of ``follow: true``. We
do not really need to follow multiple levels of symlinks, therefore now
we only follow the base directory symlink if needed.

Change-Id: Id1eca14b0a96e5395d778a0666ece87bde8e6c92
'}]
commit_message:
Fix error when the git folder contains broken symlinks

When the git repository folder contains symbolic links pointing to non
existant files, the task would fail because of ``follow: true``. We
do not really need to follow multiple levels of symlinks, therefore now
we only follow the base directory symlink if needed.

Change-Id: Id1eca14b0a96e5395d778a0666ece87bde8e6c92
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-repo_server refs/changes/43/370443/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Adding reno release notes for multiple backend feature

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/90/370390/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- prelude: > In Newton release, now within a single deployment, multiple secret store plugin backends can be configured and used. With this change, a project adminstrator can pre-define a preferred plugin backend for storing their secret. New APIs are added to manage this project level secret store preference. features: - New feature to support multiple secret store plugin backends. This feature is not enabled by default. To use this feature, related feature flag needs to be enabled and supporting configuration needs to be added in service configuration. Once enabled, project adminstrator shall be able to specify one of available secret store backend as a preference for their project key material. This secret store preference applies only to new secrets (key material) created/stored and existing secrets are not impacted. Refer to Barbican multiple backends setup and API documentation for further details.
